did.abstract: Ann Arbor, Mich. resident and businessman with strong interest in local history. Collection includes video featuring interviews with residents and other historical footage of landmarks and events in Ann Arbor, Ypsilanti, and the hamlet of Dixboro as well as collected papers and records related to Ann Arbor High School and Dixboro United Methodist Church.

bioghist.p: Dale Leslie, a life-long Ann Arborite, is an active local history steward and community volunteer in the greater Ann Arbor, Michigan area. Leslie earned master's degrees from Ohio University and the University of Michigan as well as a bachelor's degree from Eastern Michigan University. From 1961-1997, Leslie owned and operated Leslie Office Supply, Inc. The business was sold in 1997.

Leslie has been active in several Ann Arbor area community groups. Leslie is on the board of directors for the Washtenaw County Historical Society, a member and former president of the Kiwanis Club of Ann Arbor, a former executive committee member of the Ann Arbor Area Chamber of Commerce, a former member of the City of Ann Arbor Cable Communications Commission, and a member of the Ann Arbor First Presbyterian Church.

arrangement.p: The Dale R. Leslie papers collection is comprised of two series: Michigan History and Interviews.

scopecontent.p: Most of the collection consists of digitized film footage and digital video relating to Ann Arbor and Michigan history.

scopecontent.p: The Michigan History series (3 folders and 4.44 GB) includes images, recordings, and interviews on the subject of local history, events, and landmarks. It is divided into three subseries according to geographic locations covered by the material: Ann Arbor, Detroit, and Dixboro and Superior Township.

The Ann Arbor History subseries (1 folder, 3GB) includes various video and paper materials related to events and people from Ann Arbor. It also contains a program and a commemorative video recording from the 50 year reunion of the 1962 state champion Ann Arbor High School football team. Also included is footage of the building of Ann Arbor High School in the 1950s, the memorial service for University of Michigan athletic standout Don Lund, and videos of various individuals who spoke at local Kiwanis Club meetings.
The Detroit History subseries (1 folder, 0.8GB) consists of one digitized CD audio called Motor City Radio Reunion.

The Dixboro and Superior Township History subseries (1 folder, 0.64GB) consists of several informative videos and a recorded speeches about the history of Dixboro, particularly the Dixboro United Methodist Church. Also included is a silent film, with new narration by Dale Leslie, from 1941 called Sweet Genevieve.

did.unittitle: Ann Arbor High School Football 50 Year Reunion

odd.p: (This video features highlights from the 1962 Ann Arbor High School football season. The team went undefeated and won the Class A State Championships. The video is narrated by Jay Stielstra who was the head coach of the 1962 team.)

did.unittitle: Dale R. (for "Radio") Leslie Presents Big Ten Medley, undated

odd.p: (Fight songs from Big Ten schools, including the Ohio State Merry-Go-'round Song)

(In the early 1950s a new high school was built in Ann Arbor high school on Main Street and West Stadium Boulevard. Mahlon Buell, a physics teacher in the high school (1922-58) filmed the evolution of the project. Buell, along with Gene D. Maybee (Tappan Junior High School principal, 1963-70) and Gail Beaver (administrative assistant) narrate the footage.)

(This video is of the memorial service for Ann Arbor resident Don Lund. The service took place in 2013 and eulogies were provided by Bob Foreman and Ed Hood. Don Lund played football, baseball and basketball at the University of Michigan in the 1940s. Lund went on to play baseball professionally for seven years. Following his career in the MLB, Lund coached U-M baseball and worked as an administrator for the Detroit Tigers and the U-M athletic office.)

(This video is a tribute to U.S. military veterans, past and present, who were and are members of the Ann Arbor First Presbyterian Church. The video was created by Gary Stahl, a parishioner at the church.)

(Looking back over 65 years, the management and staff of the University of Michigan owned-radio station, WUOM, informally paid tribute to a pair of their early renown broadcasters at a reception in the Alumni Center during the Ann Arbor Summer Festival in 2013. The broadcasters recognized were Hazen Schumacher and Dr. William (Bill) Stegath.)

did.unittitle: Kiwanis Club of Ann Arbor Presentations

odd.p: (The Ann Arbor Kiwanis Club hosted a Super Divisional Inter-club meeting on September 21, 2011 that featured speaker Art Holst. Holst is well know for his motivation and insightful stories of action on and off the field while officiating in the NFL.)

did.unittitle: Neal Boudette (Wall Street Journal Detroit Bureau Chief) 2012

odd.p: (Neal Boudette, Wall Street Journal Detroit Bureau Chief and Ann Arbor resident, is the featured speaker for the Kiwanis Club of Ann Arbor Morning Edition meeting on January 18, 2012. Boudette answers questions and discusses his views about the future of Detroit and the state of the auto industry in Detroit.)

(The murders of seven young women in the 1960s shocked the Ann Arbor and Ypsilanti area. At the Kiwanis Club of Ann Arbor Morning Edition meeting, June 29, 2011, the chief law enforcement officer, former Washtenaw County Sherrif Douglas J. Harvey reflects on the investigation leading to the arrest of John Norman Collings. Bill Treml, former Ann Arbor News crime beat reporter, also contributes his recollections.)
(WWWJ's broadcast celebrating ten decades of broadcasting in Detroit)

odd.p: (The Dixboro United Methodist Church is the oldest house of worship utilized weekly in Michigan. The video features photographs and historical footage of things related to the church and is narrated by church member, Richard Leslie.)

(Dixboro Church Historian, the late Ivan Parker and his sister, the late Leona Parker Bunnell, talk about the history of the Dixboro school. Parker and Bunnell were both students and later teachers at the school.)

(As the laity Sunday speaker in October 1982, Harvey Sanderson discusses some of the "risks" the Dixboro United Methodist church has taken such as building an education wing, a fellowship hall, and acquiring the Village Green. The audio of his speach is set to a video featuring historical photographs of the church and of Sanderson.)

(This 1941 silent movie was written, cast, filmed, produced and directed by Melvin Schumaker of Superior Township, Michigan. The cast was composed of individuals from the Frains Lake Players group. Parts of the film takes place in Ypsilanti, Michigan. Dale Leslie has added narration to the film that provides context about the production and individual actors. Leslie's father, Dick Leslie, was an actor in the film. The actors were as follows: Helen Litke Hermanns (Genevieve), Gus Hansen (John Clark), Dick Leslie (Georg Books), Grace Conklin Patrick (Mother), Chester Martin (Father), and Joanne Galpin (daughter).)

(Dale Leslie leads a tour of Dixboro and discusses the history of the hamlet with Carol Freeman in the summer of 1989. Freeman authored a book, "Of Dixboro: Lest We Forget." Part of the video features the Dixboro United Methodist Church which was built in 1858 and is the oldest house of worship utilized weekly in the State of Michigan. The video was produced and directed by Art Vuolo, Jr.)

scopecontent.p: The Interviews series (1 folder, 3.84GB) features interviews performed or collected by Dale Leslie. The interviewees are members of the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Brighton and Ypsilanti communities.

odd.p: (This video is the story of Austin Smith, an 8 year old photographer from Brighton, Michigan, who is also autistic.)

(This video, presented by the Michigan Political History Society, features an interview with Peter B. Fletcher (b. 1932 - d. 2012). Fletcher owned The Credit Bureau of Ypsilanti and was active in Michigan politics. The interview took place on October 15, 2008. The interviewer is Bill Ballenger, a former state legislator and owner-publisher of "Inside Michigan Politics.")

did.unittitle: Recollections of the Ann Arbor Air Force, 2009

odd.p: (In this interview, Dale Leslie speaks with the Ann Arbor Air Force air show members. Interviewees are Bob Barden, Sr., wingwalker Eddie "The Grip" Green, Bob Lyjak, Danny Clisham and Jim Mynning. In a panel discussion, the men discuss past adventures and performances. The opening 3 minutes feature historical footage of the Ann Arbor Air Force in action. Originally broadcast on Community Television Network.)

(In this interview, Dale Leslie speaks with Al Renfrew. Renfrew was a player on the 1948 NCAA Championship Ice Hockey Team, head coach of the 1964 NCAA Championship Ice Hockey Team, and ticket manager for the athletic department. Renfrew, 88 years old at the time of the interview, reflects on his time at the University of Michigan.)

(This interview with Don Staebler and farm tour was conducted on November 30, 2011. The Staebler family began farming in Superior Township in 1912. Staebler, 100 years old at the time of the interview, shares stories about what is was like growing up and making a living as a farmer in Michigan. The Staebler farm and land are now preserved as a Washtenaw County park.)

(In this interview Dr. William Stegath shares his experience as one of only three play-by-play announcers of University of Michigan football on WUOM radio in Ann Arbor. Dr. Stegath was also a professor of Radio and TV Broadcasting at Michigan, a former assistant executive director of the Alumni Association, and the first camp director at Camp Michigania, an alumni camp in North Michigan. Dr. Stegath is originally from Escanaba, MI.)

(This interview with Dr. Edgar E. Willis took place on the eve of his 100th birthday in July 2013. Willis was a distinguished professor of Radio and TV Broadcasting at Michigan. The interview focuses on his career and Willis also discusses three colleagues: Dr. Edward Stasheff, Dr. Henry R. Austin, and Dr. Frank Beaver.)
(Interview with Russ Woinowsk, World War II and Korean War veteran, for the Veterans History Project and Ypsilanti Rotary Club.)
